content.description: Forgettable start leads to a fun mini-roof pull. Holds to make it past the roof stump a lot of people, but they're there.
content.location: Left of "Right Hand Rosie". Starts just to the right of the tree.

content.description:
Climb slightly less than vertical rock past a large, volleyball-sized cobble to the fourth bolt (it looks almost like you could sit on the large cobble).

Continue up more difficult, somewhat overhanging rock through another couple of bolts; the angle eases before the chains.
content.location:
Walk along the base of

The Matrix

until an outside corner. The route is the second bolted line  after the corner and climbs up past an obvious large cobble. Constructed terraces start below the route.

content.description: Climb left of the black water streak. Long sustained and quality route. Has pockets.

Climb slightly overhanging rock using jugs, slopers, sidepulls, and some less positive holds. The crux is probably between bolts three and four; good footwork helps.

After bolt five the angle eases to slightly less than vertical. The chains are just before the overhanging rock above the route.
content.location:
Walk along the base of

The Matrix

until an outside corner. The route is just after the corner and climbs the left side of the corner's arete. Constructed terraces start just after the route location and there is a large evergreen tree on the left when facing the terraces.
Climb the flute in the rock.

content.description:
Straight forward climbing up dishes and cobbles to an obvious downward-facing "molar cobble" at the bulge. Pull bouldery moves over the bulge on relatively small holds to bigger holds to the top.

The route is new as of early June 2018 so use caution on suspect holds and expect it to be a bit dirty for a while.
content.protection: Five bolts to anchor with lowering biners.
content.location: Left of the tree by the trail. The "molar cobble" sticking down out of the crux bulge is easy to identify.

content.description: Kind of dirty climbing until you pull a very thin crimpy bulge/roof. Tough clip for shorter people. Pull the roof up to a good jug, then it's easy as you trend up and right.
content.protection: 4-5 draws to chains. Anchors shared with the 11 to the right.
content.location: Route is second from the right. Just right of Right Hand Rosie. Left of Erectile Dysfunction.

content.description:
After the no-hands rest at the anchors of

Sound the Klaxon

, head up and right on good holds as the rock steepens. A difficult lip encounter guards the easier climbing to the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts on the extension to chain anchors with biners
content.location:
Climb

Sound the Klaxon

and then keep going up and right from the anchors.

content.description: A very short 1-2 move wonder pulling the roof. A fun warmup for other routes in the area. 11c in the guidebook. I felt it was soft for the grade.
content.location: First climb from the right. This has an obvious roof.

climbs.name: Baker’s Dozen (link-up of Sounding the Klaxon into 13th Donut)

content.description: Climb Sounding the Klaxon 10b into the 13th Donut.  Equally fun alternative start instead of starting with Twelve Tasting Donuts 10c, although use it’s anchor to start into extension.

This route is phenomenal, a must do for sure!  Climb gently overhanging rock for about 45' and try and conserve your energy.  The crux comes a little past halfway where the angle kicks back a few more degrees and the holds get smaller.  If your super pumped after the crux then watch out or the next few moves might get you.
content.protection: 10 or so bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This route is not in Jason's guide but it is two routes left of "Sound of Klaxon".  At the time of this writing "12a" is written in chalk at the start of the route.

content.description: Long, slightly overhanging route on the left side of The Matrix.  Crux is about 3/4 up where the grade steepens and you have to work out a technical sequence of crimpers and small side-pulls.  Take advantage of the marginal rest before the crux - you'll need it!
content.location: This route is not in the Jason Stevens guidebook but is 3 routes left of "Sound the Klaxon".  At the time of this writing, "11c" is written in chalk at the base of the route.

content.description:
From the no-hands stance at the anchors of The

Twelve Tasty Donuts

, continue up on steepening rock to some worse-than-they look cruxy holds at the lip. Better holds above the lip lead to the anchors.
content.location:
Climb

Twelve Tasty Donuts

to the anchors and then continue up above.

climbs.name: A Place Where I Can Hide

content.description:
Face climbing followed by stemming on less-than-vertical terrain, followed by some exciting stemming under an overhang (it's hard to call it a roof because it is so rounded.) The chains are just above the overhang.

There is a fair amount of loose material on this route and we liberated several baseball-sized stones as well as a number of marble-sized pieces. The loosest section is runout about fifteen feet; fortunately the climbing through the section is fairly easy stemming. The only anxiety arises from looking down between your legs and thinking that you're getting kind of far from the previous bolt.
content.protection: 9 bolts to chain anchors with cord backup. The last bolt is non-obvious; it is on the left side of the overhang near the top.
content.location: This climbs an obvious, shallow trough to an overhang. Above and behind the overhang a deep crevice continues. This is located shortly before the outside corner in the wall, beyond which are constructed terraces.

content.description: Fun, on-your-feet climbing up a very blunt arete of sorts. Hard to see/find holds make this a bit pumpier than your standard 5.9. A fun bulge encounter on big holds at the tops leads to anchors way off to the left.
content.protection: Six bolts to chains off to the left after the bulge up high.
content.location: This is the left edge of the part of the wall facing the main middle fork trail. The first bolt is about 9 feet up.
